Effect of CO2/propane ratio and trimetallic oxide catalysts on maximizing dry reforming of propane Emad. Sanhoob Methodology Validation b a Research and Development Center, Saudi Aramco, Dhahran 31311, Saudi Arabia Research and Development Center Saudi Aramco Dhahran 31311 Saudi Arabia aResearch and Development Center, Saudi Aramco, Dhahran 31311, Saudi Arabia b Interdisciplinary Research Center for Hydrogen and Energy Storage (IRC-HES), King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia Interdisciplinary Research Center for Hydrogen and Energy Storage (IRC-HES) King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Dhahran 31261 Saudi Arabia bInterdisciplinary Research Center for Hydrogen and Energy Storage (IRC-HES), King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia ⁎ Corresponding author. This study aimed at increasing the dry reforming reaction of propane with CO2 by using trimetallic oxide catalyst based on the reactive support of ZrO2/TiO2. Multiple basic (Mg, Be and Ba) and transition metal oxide (Cu, Fe) and Al were impregnated separately into 5%ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst support and characterized by XRD, BET, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD. The catalysts showed an increase in the number of basic surface sites, with the trimetallic catalysts exhibiting more than 2.2–9.7 times the original number of basic sites of the Zr/Ti oxide support. In order to maximize greenhouse gas conversion, selected ratios of CO2/propane were correlated to increase syngas (CO and H2) product and promote more CO2 reactions via surface intermediates from CC bond dissociation of propane. Utilizing trimetallic catalysts enabled a three folds increase of CO yield compared to the reactive support used in the study. Although the selectivity towards H2 and CO increase with trimetallic catalysts, 2%Fe/5%ZrO2/TiO2 and 2%Be/5%ZrO2/TiO2 exhibited the highest propane dry reforming conversions (84–97%) with yields of H2 (35–51%) and CO (60–68%), respectively. The study demonstrated that each trimetallic oxide catalyst consumed CO2 differently, promoting distinct CC bond breaking patterns of propane over the catalyst surface. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane dry reforming Syngas Dry reforming thermodynamics CO2/propane ratio CO/H2 ratio Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Recent surge in global energy demands for clean fuels has aimed to an 18% increase in the hydrogen production forecast by 2040 [1,2]. The dry reforming of methane is among the promising approaches of hydrogen production with lower carbon footprint [3]. Dry reforming of methane is an effective decarbonization technology that utilizes CO2, coupled with the aid of post water-gas-shift (WGS) reaction [4], in the aim of producing up to four molecules of hydrogen from, similar to the CALCOR process [5]. The resulting syngas (CO and H2) from the dry reforming of methane can be utilized for the production of a wide range of valuable products to meet the rising demand [3,6,7]. While the dry reforming of methane shows almost full conversion of CO2 and CH4 to syngas [8,9], research on the dry reforming of non-methane gasses such as propane [3] and butane [10] remains challenging with limited yields [11]. Earlier studies used bimetallic and trimetallic oxide catalysts to overcome the constraints of byproducts from propane dry reforming [11,12] at lower temperatures (550–700 ᵒC) [3,11,12] than methane dry reforming (750–800 ᵒC) [13,14]. Accordingly, the theoretical yields for dry reforming of propane require higher CO2 ratios than that of methane dry reforming, as shown by the reaction Eqs. (1) and (2), which state that the theoretical yield of CO2/propane ratio of 3 is expected to generate mixture of syngas with CO/H2 ratio of 1.5 higher than that for dry reforming of methane. It was worth noting that dry reforming of toluene applied CO2/toluene ratio of 7 and derives a higher CO/H2 ratio of 3.5 [15]. (Eq.1) Propane dry reforming: C3H8 + 3CO2 → 6CO + 4H2 (ΔH 621.3) … (Eq.2) Methane dry reforming: CH4 + CO2 → 2CO + 2H2 (ΔH 249) … Trimetallic and bimetallic catalysts based on Rh-Ce-Zr oxide, Rh-Zr oxide and Rh-Ce oxide were utilized to study the effect of Rh particle size on propane dry reforming [3]. Gomez et al. [16] studied propane dry reforming over bimetallic and trimetallic oxides catalysts based on NiCe, NiPtCe, and CoPtCe at 550 ᵒC and at low CO2/propane ratio of 1:1, and achieved limited conversion of propane (∼5–10%) while CO2 conversion was found to be three times higher than propane. Solymosi et al. utilized Re/Al2O3 [17] as a bimetallic catalyst to study the effect of increasing CO2/propane ratios from 3 to 6, achieving increased propane conversion from ∼50% to ∼80%. The study observed that a CO2/propane ratio of 6 resulted in reduced coke formation over the catalyst surface, with better selectivity and higher yields of syngas. Similar observation addressed by Nikoo et al. (2011), the carbonic formation declined as an increase of CO2/CH4 ratio for methane dry reforming [18]. Siahvashi et al. [11] studied the effect of varying CO2/propane ratios between 1 and 8 at dry reforming temperatures ranging between 550 and 700 ᵒC over trimetallic Mo-Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. They highlighted that a CO2/propane ratio of 3 at dry reforming temperature of 700 ᵒC was resulted in the optimum reaction conditions to increase syngas selectivity and achieve higher CO2 conversion. Råberg et al. [19] utilized Ni oxide-based catalysts and studied the effect of weak and moderate acidic (Al2O3, SiO2) and basic (CaO, MgO) catalyst supports, as well as combined supports of Mg-Al oxide, for propane reforming via CO2/propane ratio of 3 along with co-feeding of H2 and steam to maximize yields. The study achieved CO2 and propane conversions were ∼60% and ∼50%, respectively. The study showed that optimum conversions are made via Ni-oxide catalyst with moderate basic support (NiMg oxide) and also with mixed basic-acidic support catalysts (NiMgAl oxide), which showed more stable time-on-stream and higher CO selectivity. A mechanistic study on NiMgAl oxide catalyst conducted by Jensen et al. [20] demonstrated that the CC bond dissociation is the rate determining step of propane dry reforming, yielding methane as the main byproduct. Also, they showed that co-feeding CO2 during propane dry reforming, allows for achieving higher propane conversions than in the absence of CO2. Similar observations were made by Solymosi et al. [17], who investigated the kinetics of propane dry reforming and CO2. Another study investigated the overcome of thermodynamics of propane dry reforming over FeCeAl and NiCeAl oxide catalysts by increasing dry reforming temperatures (650–750 ᵒC) [21]. The study showed that higher temperatures resulted in increasing CO2 and propane conversion up to ∼60–93% and ∼40–78%, receptively. Increasing the temperature allows for surpassing the thermodynamics that govern the generation of propane dry-reforming byproducts, resulting in higher CO and H2 concentrations within the product stream. Although both catalysts showed stable CO/H2 ratios, FeCeAl oxide catalyst made a stable conversion with coke resistance. In this study, the catalyst based on titania and zirconia was used and both demonstrated their potential as support and as catalysts that are reactive for light gas dehydrogenation at presence of CO2 [22] and utilized for dry reforming reaction of methane [23,24]. The trimetallic based catalysts of V/Ce/Zr [25], V/Ti-Zr [25], Fe-Zr-Ti [26], Ce-Zr-Ti [26] were utilized for dehydrogenation of butane to butenes [25] and ethylbenzene [26] in the presence of CO2. Manrı́quez et al. [27] showed that the ZrO2-TiO2 framework contained mixture of both acidic and basic surface sites, as measured by pyridine and CO2-FTIR [27,28]. Chen et al. [29] described the combined catalyst of ZrO2-TiO2 to contain moderate acidic surface sites, mainly in the form of Lewis acid sites. Additionally, the ZrO2-TiO2 framework combines the strong basic properties of ZrO2 and weak basic sites associated with TiO2 [29]. Several studies demonstrated that the acidic-basic bifunctionality of ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst can be amplified with the increase of ZrO2 concentration incorporated into TiO2 [30–33]. A successful propane dry reforming requires the selection of reactive catalysts and supports that promote higher conversion of both propane by CO2, and suppress the formation of byproducts such as methane [17], ethane and ethylene, which are the main challenge in carrying out full dry reforming. The byproducts from propane dry-reforming have different thermodynamics of dry reforming [34–36] than that of propane and require higher cracking temperatures and more reactive catalysts and support to promote further conversion with higher syngas yield. Solymosi et al. addressed the increase of CO2/CH4 ratio derived more CO2 and propane conversion [17], probably promoting more dissociation of propane and CO2 that facilitate more dry reforming over catalyst to the intermediate byproducts generated during propane reforming. In this study, the effect of varying CO2/propane ratios was investigated to increase utilization of CO2 and to drive more syngas (CO and H2) selectivity from propane dry reforming. Then the selected CO2/propane ratio was applied to examine the influence of the addition of basic metal oxide (Mg, Be and Ba) and transition metal oxide (Cu, Fe) and Al catalysts over reactive support of ZrO2-TiO2, which has never been applied for CO2-propane dry reforming, with the aim of increasing CO2 adsorption to promote higher conversion with enhanced selectivity towards syngas production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Beryllium nitrate, barium nitrate, magnesium nitrate, ferric (II) nitrate, cupper (II) nitrate, aluminum nitrate, zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrat, and titanium (IV) oxide were obtained from Alfa Aesar and Fisher Scientific, and used to synthesize Zr/Ti oxide support and trimetallic oxide based on Zr/Ti support. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The support of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 was prepared by wet impregnation method [37,38], with 2 g of zirconium (IV) oxynitrate hydrate dissolved in RO water with diluted nitric acid (0.10 N, 200 ml) at room temperature and mixed for 30 min. A weight (20 g) of TiO2 support was mixed with dissolved zirconium oxynitrate for 4 h. Then water phase was separated from catalyst powder by using centrifuge and then transferred to drying for 18 h at 100 ᵒC. The calcination of 5% ZrO2/TiO2 was carried out using high temperature furnace at 700 ᵒC at static air and held time for 5–6 h. The trimetallic catalyst was made by addition third catalyst of each Mg, Br, Be, Fe, Cu and Al salt on the pre-prepared calcined support of 5% ZrO2/TiO2. A weight of each metal salt was dissolved in R.O. water at room temperature and mixed for 30 min and followed by addition of ZrO2/TiO2 support with mixing for 4 h. The catalyst powder was separated from the water phase and sent to drying at 100 ᵒC for 18 h, and the calcination of trimetallic catalysts was carried at 700 ᵒC for 5–6 h. 2.3 Characterization The trimetallic catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) from Panalytical X'Pert PRO Diffractometer and was utilized to identify the crystalline phase of trimetallic catalysts. The catalysts textural properties were determined utilizing N2 adsorption of Micromeritics, ASAP 2420 instrument. The catalyst surface acidity was measured by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and analyzed by HIDEN CATLAB instrument. The surface basic sites of catalysts were measured by using CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) using Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instruments. The measurement of carbon content over catalysts were analyzed using an Elemental Analyzer Perkin–Elmer 2400CHN and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under air used TGA-Q50 from TA instruments. 2.4 Catalytic test for propane dry reforming Catalytic propane dry reforming was carried out using packed bed reactor made from quartz installed in vertical furnace. A weight of 0.45 g catalyst loaded into reactor and catalyst heated at 600 ᵒC under N2 flow of 50 ml min−1 for 2 h. The flow of 3 ml/min of CO2/propane ratio were adjusted by using mass flow controller for propane dry reforming. The gas product from reforming was analyzed using gas chromatography equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) connected with Haysep Q and Porapak Q columns. The conversion of catalytic dry reforming of propane and CO2 is calculated as shown in Eq. (3). The selectivity and yield of both hydrogen and CO were calculated according to the Eqs. The X-ray diffraction of the primary support of TiO2 showed mainly anatase crystalline phase and no appearance of rutile phase of titania. Similarly, the X-ray diffraction of reactive support with 5%ZrO2 addition to TiO2 showed mainly diffraction of anatase phase associated with titania and no diffraction peaks from ZrO2, which is similar to observations noted in early studies [32,42]. Likewise, the X-ray diffraction of synthesized trimetallic oxide showed anatase phase and no appearance peaks of third metal addition, due to small quantity, and indicated dissolved the third metal catalysts into the support [43]. While small diffraction peaks from rutile phase of TiO2 appeared for three catalysts 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti oxide, 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti oxide, as shown in Fig. 1. 3.2 Textural properties, surface acidity and basicity of trimetallic oxide catalysts The textural properties of trimetallic oxide catalysts synthesized by impregnation method showed that the modification was achieved and that the pore size distribution of each catalyst is different than the original support, as shown in Fig. 2 A and B. The addition of the third metal oxide made a further reduction of textural properties, as all trimetallic oxide catalysts exhibited low surface area and pore volume, as presented in Table 1 . The surface acidity of the trimetallic oxide catalysts, impregnated with both basic and transition metal oxides, was studied using NH3-TPD. Fig. 3 A shows that the addition of basic metal oxide (Ba, Be, Mg) impregnated on the support resulted in a declined of surface acidity strength. The additions of Ba and Be resulted in a decline in the total acidity, exhibiting 159 and 170 μmol/g, respectively, compared to the original acidity of the support, valuing at 215 μmol/g, as presented in Table 1. Meanwhile, the addition of Mg oxide showed the largest reduction in the surface catalyst acidity to 30 μmol/g, much lower compared to other catalysts. The addition of transition metal oxide (Fe and Cu) to the support showed the reduction of original surface acidity (105 μmol/g and 50 μmol/g, respectively), due to contribution of surface basic sites from Fe and Cu oxide [44]. Fig. 3B shows that the addition of Al oxide resulted shift the acidity strength peak from high temperature to middle temperature strength and a slight decline in the surface acidity to 190 μmol/g, lower than original support with shifting NH3 desorption peak between (100–600 ᵒC), similar to observations by Zhang et al. [45] and Camposeco et al. [46]. Accordingly, the CO2-TPD analysis (Table 1S and Fig. 1S) showed a slight increase in the number of basic surface sites with the trimetallic catalysts exhibiting more than 2.2–9.7 times the original number of basic sites of the Zr/Ti oxide support, which is essential to increase the adsorption and reaction of both CO2 and propane gas over catalysts [47,48]. The quantitative of CO2 adsorption over trimetallic results are shown in Table 1S. The CO2 desorption temperatures and represented peak area to determine the basic sites influenced by third metal incorporated over Zr/Ti oxide, showed a number of basic sites and can be characterized into three types CO2 desorption temperature over catalysts [49–51]. The weak basic sites of CO2 desorption between temperature 50–325 ᵒC probably suggested bicarbonates formation over catalysts [50–54]. The higher temperature CO2 desperation between 320 and 725 ᵒC indicated of bidentate carbonates intermediate and strong basic sites suggested through CO2 attached to less coordination oxygen state and possible reacted with basic surface oxygen anion over catalysts [50,51,55–58]. While the higher temperature above 725 ᵒC indicated of more strong basic sites distinguish by thermal decomposition [50,51,59,60] and related to oxycarbonate derived from third metal incorporated with Zr/Ti oxide. The addition of basic metal oxide (Ba, Be, Mg) showed an increase of basic sites while decline of acidic sites were detected with NH3-TPD (Fig. 3A). The addition of Mg made the highest basic sites intermediate and very strong basic sites, suggested addition of basic metal oxide promotes more oxycarbonate basic sites and higher than Zr/Ti support, while the addition of Be showed the weakest basic sites than Mg and Ba. The addition of transition metal (Fe and Cu) and Al oxide contributed more intermediate and very strong basic sites from surface oxygen anion or combined with oxycarbonate, and the addition of Fe oxide showed the highest basic sites than Cu and Al oxide addition over Zr-Ti oxide (Table 1S and Fig. 1S). 3.3 Effect of CO2/propane ratio of reactive support The reactive support of 5%ZrO2/TiO2 showed a potential conversion of propane in presence of CO2 [61]. It was selected to study catalytic propane dry reforming and the effect of five CO2/propane ratios. Fig. 4 shows that the selectivity towards CO increased from 5.9% to 32.1% with increasing CO2/propane ratios from 1:1.5 to 24.2:1. Furthermore, the 13% hydrogen selectivity slightly declined to 10.1% as CO2/propane ratio increased to 20:1. On the other hand, at higher ratio of CO2/propane 24.2:1, altered the propane conversion and declined to 29.5% due to probably more CO2 adsorption over catalyst surface. While CO selectivity maintained at 32.1% with further reduction of hydrogen selectivity (5.9%) and attributed of RWGS. H2 was obtained as a result of hydrogenation reaction Eq. (9)) of CH bond dissociation of propane, while RWGS reaction slightly consumed of adsorbed hydrogen radical species (Hads in Eq. (10)) [62,63]. Increasing CO2/propane ratios is likely to result in increased CO2 adsorption, prompting more reaction with intermediate products from CC bond dissociation of propane and made more CO product than via RWGS route. Alternatively, RWGS [62] reaction of CO2 would consume radical species of hydrogen (Hads) and avail more CO to readily react over the catalyst surface (Eq. (10)) [63]. Therefore, increasing the CO2/propane ratios could possibly assist in facilitating catalytic dry reforming of propane and byproducts by catalytically reacting more CO2 with intermediate byproducts. The Erdöhelyi et al. [64] studied the reaction pathways of adsorbed CO2 with radical intermediate species of methane (CH3*, CH2*, CH*, H* and HO*), which lead to the generation of more CO and H2, as shown in Eqs. (9) and ((11). Bradford and Vannice [65] explained that adsorbed hydroxide generates more reactive radical species, inducing further reaction with intermediates, and generating more H* and H2O. Similarly, in the excess of CO2, intermediate species based on ethane and ethylene (C2H5x*, C2H4x*) would be reactive with adsorbed species of CO2 and produce more CO and H2. Consequently, the higher syngas (CO and H2) product yield achieved at higher CO2/propane ratio would be used to promote the dry reforming of propane reaction over trimetallic catalysts. (Eq. (9)) Hydrogenation reaction: H* + H* → H2 (g) + ** (Eq. (10)) CO2 react with H*: CO2* + H* → CO + HO* +* (Eq. (11)) Intermediate reaction with CO2: CH3* + CO2* → CH3O* + CO + * 3.4 Effect of basic metal oxide addition to trimetallic catalysts The study utilized 5%ZrO2/TiO2 as a reactive support which has moderate acidic properties and impregnated with basic metal oxides (Ba, Be and Mg) [66]. The CO2-TPD showed an increase of intermedium and strong high temperature basic sites by addition of third basic metal oxide to the support (Table 1S and Fig. 1S). Accordingly, Liu 2012 [44] and Ko 2016 [67] investigated the effect of increasing the surface basic sites of PdAlTi trimetallic oxide catalysts as well as the Cu and Fe oxides on enhancing the adsorption and reaction of CO2 over the catalysts surface. The study applied CO2/propane ratio of 20:1 aiming to increase syngas (CO and H2) yield from propane dry reforming over trimetallic oxide catalysts. Dry reforming without catalyst was included in the study to compare conversion of the thermal cracking in presence of CO2 to the catalytic cracking in propane dry reforming. Thermal cracking delivered low propane conversion (20%) and low CO2 was consumed during the reaction. Alternatively, Fig. 5 A shows an increase of propane and CO2 conversion over impregnated 5%ZrO2/TiO2 with Be, Ba or Mg oxides. Furthermore, impregnating 5%ZrO2/TiO2 with Mg oxide exhibited the highest basic site of trimetallic oxide catalyst achieved higher conversion of CO2 compared to other basic metal (Be and Ba) catalyst. While the highest propane conversion (84%) was achieved over the trimetallic oxide catalyst of 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti had lower basic sites among of Ba and Mg addition, and obtained conversion over the support of 5%ZrO2/TiO2 (56%). The higher propane conversion in the following order while the basic site decreased Be > Ba > Mg. This indicated that basic metal oxides are effective additives to catalysts designed for propane dry reforming and CO2 conversion [50,51]. Elemental analysis of carbon content over basic oxide metal of trimetallic catalysts showed a decline compared to the support (Table 1) and indicated that the basic sites contribute to less carbon content over catalysts [66]. The carbon balance weight was determined for trimetallic oxide catalysts is shown in Table 2 S and with a deviation of ±5%. Addressing the formation of byproducts (C1-C3) mainly of methane combined with ethane, ethylene and propylene is very important to understand the reaction limitations that are hindering achieving higher yields of syngas products. It is shown in Fig. 5B that the selectivity towards byproducts declined with the incorporation of basic metal oxides to the reactive support. The lowest selectivity (59.2%) to byproducts was observed over the 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti oxide catalyst but it achieved higher syngas product. Alternatively, byproduct selectivity was increased over 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti oxide catalyst and reached 78.7% but it derived lower syngas product. In terms of CO selectivity, it was increased with the utilization of trimetallic oxide catalysts containing basic metal oxide. Furthermore, Be and Ba oxides showed the highest CO selectivity ranging from 58 to 61% as presented in Fig. 5C. Interestingly, 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti catalyst showed different H2 selectivity than 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Mg/5%Zr/Ti oxide catalysts, which indicated the low basic sites strength incorporated with trimetallic catalyst has different catalytic reactivity for propane dry reforming and higher selectivity than the bimetallic support (Fig. 5C), which was in line with previous study[50,51]. The achieved yields of CO and H2 over the trimetallic catalyst containing Be, Ba and Mg oxides are presented in Fig. 5D. The catalysts of 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti showed the highest yield of CO and H2 due to higher conversion of propane and CO2. Moreover, the 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti catalyst delivered higher yield of CO than 2%Mg/5%Zr/Ti. The total yield of produced syngas (CO and H2) over the trimetallic oxide catalysts was observed to be in the following order from highest to lowest 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti > 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti > 5%Zr/Ti. Although the addition of basic metal oxides demonstrated an improvement in the dry reforming reaction [51], the main challenge is to reduce the byproduct resulting from CC bond dissociation of propane. Each trimetallic oxide catalyst showed different CC bond dissociation and CO2 dry reforming reaction to overcome surface intermediates radical species and byproducts generated from propane. While the catalyst 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti with lower basic sites achieved higher CC bond dissociation of propane (Fig. 5A) and highest CO2 utilization to produce syngas product (CO and H2). 3.5 Effect of transition metal oxide and Al addition of trimetallic catalyst Liu 2012 [44] studied the potential adsorption and reaction of CO2 over transition metal oxide based on FeO and CuO catalysts. The surface acidity of catalysts were altered by the addition of the basic sites Fe and Cu oxides, which was determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 3B). The CO2-TPD showed an increase of surface basicity sites by addition third transition metal oxide and Al to the support as showed in Fig. 1S. Moreover, the addition of Al oxide shifted the original peak to medium acidic sites strength temperature. However, the trimetallic oxide catalyst 2%Al/5%Zr/Ti delivered slightly higher propane conversion (59%) than the original support 5%ZrO2/TiO2 (56%). It was worth noting that, the addition of Al oxide improved the basic sites properties of trimetallic catalyst led to obtaining CO2 conversion three times the conversion obtained by 5%ZrO2/TiO2 as shown in Fig. 6 A. Although the trimetallic oxide catalyst 2%Cu/5%Zr/Ti delivered similar CO2 conversion to 2%Al/5%Zr/Ti, higher propane conversion was achieved around 69%. The highest CO2 and propane conversion in this study were achieved over the trimetallic oxide catalyst 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti with a CO2 conversion of 34% and propane conversion of 97%. Elemental analysis of carbon content over trimetallic catalysts was lower than that of the support (Table 1), and indicated the higher CO2/propane ratio [17] and basic sites addition of transition metal promote less carbon content over catalysts [66]. The carbon balance of trimetallic oxide catalysts is with a deviation of ±5% (Table 2S). Fig. 6B shows the obtained C1-C3 byproducts (methane, ethane, ethylene and propylene) over the various catalysts. It can be observed that the addition of Al and Cu oxides decreased the selectivity towards byproducts to more than 75%, which limited the production of desired products from dry reforming of propane. On the other hand, the lowest selectivity (47.3%) towards byproducts was attained over 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti catalyst (Fig. 6B). Also, impregnating the catalyst with transition metal oxides led to increasing H2 and CO selectivity, as presented in Fig. 6C. The addition of Al oxide showed very small increase in propane conversion (Fig. 6A), but by increased of basic sites strength promote more syngas selectivity was obtained with 21% H2 and 47% CO. This is higher than the obtained results over 5%ZrO2/TiO2 support (∼10% H2 and ∼32% CO). Although the addition of Cu oxide altered the basic sites of the catalyst compared to the original catalyst, delivered the highest selectivity to CO (58%), whereas low H2 selectivity was obtained indicating more CO2 reaction with surface intermediate radical species and byproducts as described by Erdöhelyi et al. [64] and Bradford and Vannice [65]. On the other hand, the trimetallic oxide catalyst 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti has higher basic sites derived the highest selectivity to H2 (52.7%) while CO selectivity around 52.1%, which is lower than that achieved over the 2%Cu/5%Zr/Ti catalyst. Overall, the addition of transition metal oxide (Fe, Cu) and Al oxide to base catalyst improved the propane dry reforming reaction at 600 ᵒC and derived different than basic metal oxide addition. Also, it was observed that CO2 and propane conversions increased with higher selectivity towards H2 and CO. Fig. 6D shows the yield of CO and H2 generated over 2%Al/5%Zr/Ti. The total syngas yield obtained was around 48.6% which is higher than that obtained over the support (25.4%). This is attributed to 2%Al/5%Zr/Ti promotes more dry reforming of byproducts, and thus is more favored than 5%Zr/Ti oxide. The 2%Cu/5%Zr/Ti catalyst slightly improved the dry reforming of propane by increasing the conversion and interestingly the catalyst delivered high selectivity towards CO (∼58.6%) with H2 (∼25.1%). It was observed that the highest conversion of propane and CO2 was achieved over the catalyst 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti and also the highest yield of total syngas was achieved as a result of the obtained high conversion. The yield of syngas (CO and H2) increased over the reactive support impregnated with transition metal and Al oxides in the order of 5%Zr/Ti >2%Al/5%Zr/Ti >2%Cu/5%Zr/Ti >2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti oxide catalysts. In summary, the study indicated that each trimetallic oxide catalyst has different basic sites strength property possibly led to consume CO2 differently, promote distinct CC bond breaking patterns of propane [17,20] over catalyst. The excess amount of CO2 was utilized to increase the yield of CO, where CO2 reacts with adsorbed intermediate radical species and hydrogen radical species over catalysts surface [64,65]. This was to be critical in improving the catalytic activity [17] and the dissociation of more CC bonds of propane via dry reforming route over modified catalyst with extra basic sites. Certainly, the formation of byproducts (methane, ethane, ethylene and propylene) produced from CC bond dissociation during catalytic reforming in presence of CO2 are considered to hinder the achieving high conversion towards dry reforming of propane. In this study, the 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti trimetallic oxide catalysts showed the highest conversion of propane (97% and 84%, respectively) and the lowest selectivity for byproducts. In addition, compared with the state-of-the-art of propane dry reforming over different catalytic systems based on bimetallic, trimetallic and tetrametallic catalysts are represented in Table 2. The 2%Be/5% Zr/Ti oxide and 2%Fe/5% Zr/Ti oxide catalysts exhibited superior propane dry reforming activity at 600 ᵒC for higher yield of H2 and CO yield. While nickel based catalyst of NiO(25)-MgO [49] and SrNi/Al2O3 [68] showed reactive catalysts for propane dry reforming at higher temperature 700–750 ᵒC aimed to overcome the thermodynamic constraints of byproduct intermediates generated during propane dry reforming. Fig. 2S showed the highest carbon content of spent catalyst of Zr/Ti was tested using TGA to determine the regenerating catalyst under air and showed most of the coke weight lost at 600 ᵒC. On the other hand, the syngas of CO and H2 showed high yield as a result of propane dry reforming, with the two trimetallic oxide catalysts, 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti, exhibiting the highest propane conversions, as shown in Figs. 5A and 6A. Consequently, the CO/H2 ratio was affected by the dry reforming of propane over different catalysts having different basic and acidic sites properties and the CO/H2 ratio was obtained by two trimetallic oxide catalysts of 2%Fe/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Be/5%Zr/Ti in the range of 1.3 and 1.8, respectively, and closed to the theoretical CO/H2 ratio of propane dry reforming, as shown in Fig. 7 . While the two catalysts of 2%Ba/5%Zr/Ti and 2%Cu/5%Zr/Ti showed higher CO/H2 ratio in the range 3.2 and 2.9, respectively, suggesting a more CO2 reactions with intermediates and via CC bond dissociation reactions as described by Erdöhelyi et al. [64] and Bradford and Vannice [65], which led to higher CO yield. On the whole, the CO2 conversion was affected by addition of third metals over reactive support, in which a slight increase in the number of intermediate and strong strength of surface basic sites enabled achieving higher propane and CO2 conversions. The study highlighted that high CO2/propane ratio is essential in enhancing dry reforming and increasing CO2 adsorption over trimetallic catalysts, in which more CC bond dissociation of propane was achieved with higher syngas yields over modified catalysts than the original Zr/Ti oxide catalyst base. 4 Conclusion The addition of third metal oxide based on basic and transition metal oxide improved the catalysts basic properties needed to increase the CO2 and propane adsorptions and reactions over the catalyst surface. The study demonstrated that each trimetallic oxide catalyst consumed CO2 differently, promoting distinct CC bond dissociation patterns of propane over the catalyst surface. The higher syngas (CO and H2) product achieved at higher CO2/propane ratio was used to promote the dry reforming of propane reaction over trimetallic catalysts. Utilizing trimetallic catalysts enabled a three folds increase of CO yield compared to the reactive support used in the study. Although a noticeable increase of catalytic dry reforming of propane conversion was observed in all trimetallic oxide catalysts applied in this study, the addition of Fe and Be oxides in trimetallic oxide catalysts enabled achieving the highest propane dry reforming. The byproducts from CC bond dissociation of propane remained the main challenge towards achieving full conversion of propane dry reforming. More studies are needed to address this challenge and overcome the thermodynamic condition that promotes the generation of byproducts from propane during dry reforming process. coredata.dc:description: This study aimed at increasing the dry reforming reaction of propane with CO2 by using trimetallic oxide catalyst based on the reactive support of ZrO2/TiO2. Multiple basic (Mg, Be and Ba) and transition metal oxide (Cu, Fe) and Al were impregnated separately into 5%ZrO2/TiO2 catalyst support and characterized by XRD, BET, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD. The catalysts showed an increase in the number of basic surface sites, with the trimetallic catalysts exhibiting more than 2.2–9.7 times the original number of basic sites of the Zr/Ti oxide support. In order to maximize greenhouse gas conversion, selected ratios of CO2/propane were correlated to increase syngas (CO and H2) product and promote more CO2 reactions via surface intermediates from CC bond dissociation of propane. Utilizing trimetallic catalysts enabled a three folds increase of CO yield compared to the reactive support used in the study. Although the selectivity towards H2 and CO increase with trimetallic catalysts, 2%Fe/5%ZrO2/TiO2 and 2%Be/5%ZrO2/TiO2 exhibited the highest propane dry reforming conversions (84–97%) with yields of H2 (35–51%) and CO (60–68%), respectively. The study demonstrated that each trimetallic oxide catalyst consumed CO2 differently, promoting distinct CC bond breaking patterns of propane over the catalyst surface.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of CO2/propane ratio and trimetallic oxide catalysts on maximizing dry reforming of propane
